author: .vbuterin
content:
As I remember:

* Average witness size (assuming binary trees and code merklization): ~500-700 kB
* Theoretical max witness size (assuming targeted "attack blocks" and my proposed gas repricings): ~3-4 MB

author: .vbuterin
content: We have had 500 kB blocks on mainnet before as part of starkware's tests, and it did disrupt some bootstrap nodes as I remember, though mining was completely un-disrupted; no noticeable change in uncle rate

author: .vbuterin
content: Technically, clients would not need to *store* witnesses

author: .vbuterin
content:
> Would it lead to lower gas limits to compensate?

I actually hope that stateless can open the door to *higher* gas limits!

author: .vbuterin
content: Another thing to keep in mind is that in the longer run (2+ years?) the witness size drops to ~100-200 kB because we'll have witness compression with fancy SNARK/STARKs

author: phabc
content:
> Technically, clients would not need to store witnesses
> As witnesses can be recomputed
> I actually hope that stateless can open the door to higher gas limits!
Right, since state size will be lower, but I would imagine it would take much longer to sync a full node if we raise the gas limit, especially if dealing with witnessess slows down validation (which I assume it does, but may not).

> he witness size drops to ~100-200 kB because we'll have witness compression with fancy SNARK/STARKs
Yeah using these would def make witnesses a lot more interesting, though this does seem indeed like a 3-5 years vision and imo might be dangeroud to rely on for short/medium term decisions.

author: .vbuterin
content: > especially if dealing with witnessess slows down validation (which I assume it does, but may not).

author: .vbuterin
content: It may actually speed it up

author: pipermerriam
content: Readily available witnesses from the network potentially do away with the *need* for an SSD as you can do all of your reads from the witness, and only use the disk for batched writes.  (Implicitely this also should speed up block processing/validation)
